title: A significant number of Chinese economists argued that the inflationary problems of 1985—6 could not be explained in terms of macroeconomic imbalance. They therefore rejected the view that inflation could be brought under control by fiscal and monetary contraction without adverse effects upon the growth rate. They viewed inflation as the result of microeconomic imbalance (or what Kornai calls 'shortage') which could be corrected by enterprise reform aimed at reallocating factors of production to more productive sectors of the economy
